caption: Table 1: Comparisons of dynamic regret guarantees with previous works studying adversarial linear mixture MDPs with the unknown transition and full-information feedback. Here, d is the feature mapping dimension, H is the episode length, K is the number of episodes, PK and PK are two kinds of non-stationarity measure defined in (3) satisfying PK < HPK [Zhao et al., 2022, Lemma 6].
description: This table compares the dynamic regret guarantees of different algorithms for solving adversarial linear mixture Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) with unknown transition and full-information feedback.  It shows the dependence of the dynamic regret on various factors such as feature dimension (d), episode length (H), number of episodes (K), and a non-stationarity measure (PK or PK). The table highlights the differences in the results obtained with different algorithms and whether prior knowledge of the non-stationarity measure was assumed.

caption: Table 1: Comparisons of dynamic regret guarantees with previous works studying adversarial linear mixture MDPs with the unknown transition and full-information feedback. Here, d is the feature mapping dimension, H is the episode length, K is the number of episodes, PK and PK are two kinds of non-stationarity measure defined in (3) satisfying PK < HPK [Zhao et al., 2022, Lemma 6].
description: This table compares the dynamic regret bounds achieved by different algorithms in the literature for solving adversarial linear mixture Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) with unknown transition dynamics and full-information feedback.  It shows the dependence of the regret on key parameters: the feature dimension (d), episode length (H), number of episodes (K), and a measure of non-stationarity (PK or PK). The table highlights the improvement of the proposed algorithm over existing methods, particularly in handling unknown non-stationarity.
